title: 109_hr5375
content:
The Act titled "New Options Petroleum Energy Conservation Act of 2006" provides a credit for electricity produced from climate neutral combustion processes. The Act "New Options Petroleum Energy Conservation Act of 2006" offers a credit for electricity generated from climate neutral combustion processes, defining a climate neutral combustion resource as any fuel used in a qualified facility. The Act "New Options Petroleum Energy Conservation Act of 2006" provides a credit for electricity produced from climate neutral combustion facilities. A qualified facility must capture carbon dioxide, have no atmospheric emissions of mercury or greenhouse gases, and be owned by the taxpayer. The amendments apply to electricity generated after December 31, 2006. SEC. 3. Extends the energy credit for solar energy property from 2008 to 2012. Applies to taxable years ending after December 31, 2007. 

SEC. 4. Extends the credit for residential energy efficient property from 2007 to 2011. Applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2007.

SEC. 5. Introduces a prize program. SEC. 5 introduces a prize program offering $1 billion to the first US automobile manufacturer to produce and sell 60,000 midsized sedans that run on gasoline and achieve 100 miles per gallon. SEC. 6 authorizes $30 million for lithium ion battery technology development. SEC. 7 allows expensing of property used in refining ethanol, methanol, and biodiesel. SEC. 179E allows expensing of property used in refining ethanol, methanol, and biodiesel. A taxpayer can elect to treat the cost of qualified biofuel property as an expense, deductible in the year the property is placed in service. The election must be made on the tax return and cannot be revoked without the Secretary's consent. Qualified biofuel property is defined as property used for refining biofuel with the taxpayer's original use. The term 'biofuel' includes qualified methanol or ethanol fuel and biodiesel. For dual-use property used for biofuel refining and other purposes, the cost for tax purposes is adjusted based on usage ratios. Section 179C does not apply to property considered under this provision, and recapture rules apply if the property no longer qualifies as biofuel property. Conforming amendments are also made. Conforming amendments are made to the tax code to include deductions for expenditures related to biofuel property under section 179E. Chapter 1 of the tax code is amended to include a new item after section 179D. Section 179E allows for the expensing of certain property used in refining ethanol, methanol, and biodiesel. The amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act.
